holdings.text: The situs of the sales by the respondents to the non-resident parties was within the Madras area at Bellary where sales were completed and delivery took place.

anchor.surface_text: The course of transactions found by the Tribunal, reproduced above, led the Tribunal and the High Court to the finding that the situs of the sales by the respondents to the non- resident parties was in Bellary where

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirmed lower courts' finding based on facts: orders placed, goods consigned to buyers, delivery to common carrier as buyer's agent within state, buyers obtained permits and insured goods as owners.

holdings.text: Delivery was within the State as common carrier took delivery as agent of the buyer; buyers recognised ownership by insuring goods during transit.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this submission. It has been rightly held by the High Court that the common carrier took delivery as agent of the buyer and that delivery was within the State. There is the further

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejected claim that sales completed outside state; carrier acted as buyer's agent, insurance by buyers confirmed transfer of property within state.

holdings.text: The sales were not sales in the course of inter-State trade.

anchor.surface_text: The nature of transactions found by the Tribunal in the cases before us shows that property in the cotton bales sold by the respondents did not pass during the movement of goods from one State to another by transfer of documents of title, and, further, that the movement of goods from the Madras area to places outside the State was not the result of any covenant or incident of the contract of sale.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied s.3(a),(b) Central Sales Tax Act via precedent (Tata Iron case): property passed within state before movement; movement not incident of contract but by buyers post-purchase.

holdings.text: A non-resident buyer who buys cotton in the State can be the last dealer not exempt from taxation under Rule 4-A(iv)(b); tax levied on dealer who buys in the State regardless of residence or location.

anchor.surface_text: According to him, it is the situs of the seller and the buyer which determines the applicability of this Rule, and not the situs of the sale of cotton itself. We are unable to accept this submission. The language of the Rule is clear that the tax is to be levied from the dealer who buys it in the State and is the last dealer not exempt from taxation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of Rule 4-A(iv)(b): key is 'buys it in the State', not residence; distinguished from hypothetical 'dealer in the State'; applied to facts where purchases occurred in state.

holdings.text: The respondents were not the last dealers under s.5(2) read with Rule 4-A(iv)(b); the non-resident buyers were the last dealers who bought in the State, so tax levied on them not respondents.

anchor.surface_text: On these facts, the question that fell for determination was whether for purposes of s. 5(2) of the Act read with Rule 4-A(iv)(b) of the Rules, the respondents were the dealers who bought the cotton in the State and were the last dealers not exempt from taxation under s. 3(3) of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combined situs within state, non-inter-state nature, and Rule interpretation: buyers purchased and took property in state as last non-exempt dealers (mills for manufacture).

holdings.text: Alternative contention that outside buyers were not dealers cannot be raised for first time in Supreme Court.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural bar: points not urged before lower courts inadmissible in appeal.

precedents.citation: Tata Iron and Steel Co. Limited, Bombay v. S. R. Sarkar and Others 1

anchor.surface_text: Tata Iron and Steel Co. Limited, Bombay v. S. R. Sarkar and Others 1 , where clauses  a   b  of s. 3 of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956 were interpreted as follows In our view, therefore, within cl. b  of s. 3 are included sales in which property in the goods passes during the movement of the goods from one State to another by transfer of documents of title thereto cl. a  of s. 3 covers sales, other than those included in cl. b , in which the movement of goods from one State to another is the result of a covenant or incident of the contract of sale, and property in the goods passes in either State.  1  1961  1  S.C.R. 379.

precedents.case_name: Tata Iron and Steel Co. Limited, Bombay v. S. R. Sarkar and Others
precedents.cited_proposition: sales in the course of inter-State trade under clauses (a) and (b) of s. 3 of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956
precedents.cited_holding: In our view, therefore, within cl. (b) of s. 3 are included sales in which property in the goods passes during the movement of the goods from one State to another by transfer of documents of title thereto cl. (a) of s. 3 covers sales, other than those included in cl. (b), in which the movement of goods from one State to another is the result of a covenant or incident of the contract of sale, and property in the goods passes in either State.
